![Image](data:image/png;base64,)

## SCIENTIFIC REVIEW

## A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Sentinel Lymph Node Biopsy in Gastric Cancer, an Optimization of Imaging Protocol for Tracer Mapping

Yuqiang Huang 1,2 · Mengting Pan 2 · Bo Chen 1,2

Accepted: 27 November 2020 / Published online: 3 January 2021 /C211 Springer Nature Switzerland AG part of Springer Nature 2021

## Abstract

Background Sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) plays an essential role in the evaluation of lymph node (LN) metastasis status and the extent of LN dissection in gastric cancer. The aim of our study was to perform a systematic review and meta-analysis for corresponding identification rate and sensitivity of different SLNB techniques.

Methods Systematic search using PubMed, Embase, and Cochrane library databases was conducted for studies on SLNB in patients with gastric cancer. Studies were stratified according to the sentinel lymph node (SLN) biopsy technique: blue dye (BD), radiocolloid tracer (RI), indocyanine green (ICG), a combination of radiocolloid with blue dye (RI ? BD), and a combination of radiocolloid with ICG (RI ? ICG). A random-effect model was used to pool the identification rate, sensitivity, and accuracy.

Results A total of 54 eligible studies (3767 patients) was included. The pooled identification rates of SLNB using BD, RI, ICG, RI ? BD, RI ? ICG were 95% (95%CI: 92-97%), 95% (95%CI: 93-97%), 99% (95%CI: 97-99%), 97% (95%CI: 96-98%), and 95% (95%CI: 87-99%), respectively. The pooled sensitivities were 82% (95%CI: 77-86%), 87% (95%CI: 81-92%), 90% (95%CI: 82-95%), 89% (95%CI: 84-93%), and 88% (95%CI: 79-94%), respectively. The pooled accuracies were 94% (95%CI: 91-96%), 95% (95%CI: 92-97%), 98% (95%CI: 95-99%), 97% (95%CI: 95-99%), and 98% (95%CI: 95-99%), respectively.

Conclusions The current meta-analysis provides reliable evidence that favors the use of ICG and dual tracer method (RI ? BD/ICG) for the identification of the SLN. Considering the high costs and potential biohazard of using radioactive substances in dual tracer method, performing SLNB with ICG is the technique of choice for experienced surgeons.

## Introduction

Yuqiang Huang and Mengting Pan contributed equally to this work.

Supplementary information The online version contains supplementary material available at (https://doi.org/10.1007/s00268020-05900-9).

& Bo Chen

chenbo7892@xmu.edu.cn

- 1 Department of Clinical Medicine, Fujian Medical University, Fuzhou 350122, China
- 2 Department of Gastrointestinal Surgery, Xiamen Cancer Center, The First Affiliated Hospital of Xiamen University, 55 Zhenhai Road, Xiamen 361003, China

![Image](data:image/png;base64,)

Gastric cancer (GC) is one of the most common malignant tumors worldwide and the third leading cause of cancerrelated deaths [1]. Currently, surgical resection with regional lymph node (LN) dissection is main effective intervention for cure or long-term survival of patients with GC, and accurate evaluation of lymph node metastasis is crucial for the choice of treatment options and determining prognosis. Sentinel lymph node (SLN) is defined as the hypothetical first site to receive the lymphatic drainage from the primary tumor. Furthermore, the lymphatic metastatic status of downstream lymph nodes is believed to

![Image](data:image/png;base64,)

be correlated with the pathological results of SLNs [2]. The concept of SLN has been validated in various tumors, and sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) has been successfully applied with promising results to evaluate the presence of LN metastasis in GC, allowing a reduction in the extent of surgical intervention with limited lymph node dissection [3-5].

In the present study, available methods used for SLN mapping include blue dye (BD), radiocolloid tracer (RI), indocyanine green (ICG), a combination of radiocolloid with blue dye (RI ? BD), and a combination of radiocolloid with ICG (RI ? ICG) [6-8]. However, there is no consensus on the best protocol for its clinical use in SLN mapping and how to supplement or replace other traditional SLNB techniques.

The BD method is convenient and cost-effective. However, it has certain limitations, such as the rapid transit of the dye after injection and loss of visibility in dense adipose tissue, making it hard to detect the true sentinel nodes [9, 10]. Radiocolloid method exhibits poor SLN identification rate because of high background scattering at the primary injection site. Moreover, potential biohazard and legal considerations limit the use of the radioactive probe-guided method in general hospitals [8, 11]. The dual tracer method is considered the most reliable method, but it requires additional endoscopic examination and injection of radiolabeled colloid on the day before surgery. Further, the use of radioactive substances means that the dual tracer method can only be implemented in facilities with radiation-controlled endoscopic laboratories, which leads to high medical expenses and more operative time [12-14].

Recently, ICG infrared or fluorescence imaging has been introduced in the clinical practice as an alternative agent for SLNB guidance. However, the optimal settings of ICG infrared or fluorescence imaging for SLNB, such as ICG concentration and volume, biopsy technique and injection timing, have not been determined. Furthermore, ICG infrared or fluorescence imaging requires special laparoscopic detection equipment [15, 16].

The limitations and characteristics of each mapping technique have an effect on the ability of these modalities to evaluate the status of LN metastasis in gastric cancer, yet accurate evaluation of LN metastasis is crucial for the choice of treatment options and determining prognosis [17]. Therefore, the aim of our study is to provide a detailed meta-analysis on the ability of different SLNB techniques to predict the status of LN metastasis. Additionally, we aim to identify technical aspects influencing the identification rate, sensitivity of SLN mapping.

## Materials and methods

## Search strategy

The preferred reporting items for systematic reviews and meta-analysis (PRISMA) guidelines were used in conducting this study. A comprehensive electronic literature search was conducted using PubMed, Embase, and Cochrane Library databases from January 1, 2001 to April 25, 2020. Potentially relevant studies were searched using the following search terms ''gastric/stomach'' AND ''cancer/neoplasm/carcinoma/tumor'' AND ''sentinel lymph node/sentinel node''. Through these combined keywords, the primary collection of studies was defined. Furthermore, reference lists of relevant articles and reviews were manually screened for additional eligible studies.

## Inclusion and exclusion criteria

Inclusion criteria were as follows: (1) studies assessed the diagnostic value of BD, RI, ICG, RI ? BD, or RI ? ICG guided SLN mapping in predicting LN status of gastric cancer; (2) histopathological examination was taken as reference standard; (3) studies reported sufficient data of diagnostic performance.

Studies were excluded on the basis of following criteria: (1) studies without original patient data, such as comments, case reports, reviews, editorials, and letters; (2) in vitro studies and animal studies; (3) studies involved patients with several kinds of gastrointestinal malignancies.

Two investigators (YH and MP) independently assessed the eligibility of all retrieved articles using pre-defined inclusion and exclusion criteria. Then, repeated studies were excluded. Finally, each independent selected study was cross-checked by the aforementioned two reviewers. Any disagreement between investigators was resolved with a consensus meeting.

## Data extraction and quality assessment

The following data were extracted by two authors (YH and MP) using pre-designed forms: first author, year of publication, sample size, type of study, tracers, tumor diameter, clinical T stage, injection site, surgical methods, mean number of detected SLNs, methods of SLN biopsy, pathological methods, and test results (identification rate, sensitivity, specificity).

The methodological quality was evaluated by two independent reviewers (YH and MP) using version 2 of the quality assessment of diagnostic accuracy studies (QUADAS-2) tool [18]. QUADAS-2 tool was used to assess the risk of bias and applicability of diagnostic accuracy studies,

and each item was described with: Yes (high quality), No (low quality), or Unclear. Any controversy was resolved by consensus.

## Statistical analysis

The random-effects model based on the DerSimonian and Laird method was applied to pool the SLN identification rate, sensitivity, specificity, accuracy, and negative predictive value (NPV) with 95% confidence interval (CI) [19]. A Z-test was used to compare the pooled estimates of the diagnostic value obtained from different SLNB techniques, and P value \ 0.05 was considered statistically significant. The statistical heterogeneity among studies was evaluated using I 2 statistic, and heterogeneity was considered significant if I 2 value [ 50%.

Additional subgroup analysis to describe heterogeneity and further characterize outcomes was completed for the mean number of detected SLNs, injection site, tumor diameter, pathological methods, methods of SLN biopsy, year of publication, surgical methods, and clinical T stage.

Deeks' funnel plots asymmetry test was used to examine potential publication bias. All statistical analyses were performed using Meta-Disk software Version 1.4 (Javier Zamora, Madrid, Spain) and Stata software Version 16.0 (Stata Corporation, College Station, TX, USA).

## Results

## Study selection and description

The search strategy initially yielded 749 records. After removing duplicates and scanning the titles or abstracts, the remaining 117 studies were further assessed via the fulltext view. After thorough review, 54 studies involving 3,767 patients met the inclusion criteria and were included in this meta-analysis [3, 6, 8, 10, 11, 20-68]. The flow diagram of literature search is shown in Supplementary Fig. 1.

The principal characteristics of each mapping technique (BD, ICG, RI, RI ? BD, and RI ? ICG) are presented in Tables 1,2,3,4,5, respectively. For the evaluation of SLNB using BD (19 studies), a total of 4574 SLNs in 1060 patients was detected, with an average of 4.32 SLNs per patient. For the evaluation of SLNB using RI (9 studies), a total of 1584 SLNs in 477 patients was detected, with an average of 3.32 SLNs per patient. For the evaluation of SLNB using ICG (8 studies), a total of 3002 SLNs in 513 patients was detected, with an average of 5.85 SLNs per patient. ICG fluorescence imaging (4 studies) identified 1036 SLNs in 181 patients with an average of 5.72 SLNs per patient. ICG infrared imaging (4 studies) identified

1966 SLNs in 332 patients with an average of 5.92 SLNs per patient. For the evaluation of SLNB using RI ? BD (12 studies), a total of 5242 SLNs in 1079 patients were detected, with an average of 4.85 SLNs per patient. For the evaluation of SLNB using RI ? ICG (7 studies), a total of 2624 SLNs in 524 patients were detected, with an average of 5.01 SLNs per patient.

## Quality assessment

The QUADAS-2 tool was used to assess the methodological quality of eligible studies, and the results (Supplementary Fig. 2) suggested that all included studies were of moderately high quality. Of these included studies, author's judgement for risk of bias depicted high risk of bias in 7 (13.0%) studies according to patient selection, while 4 (7.4%) studies had high risk of bias according to the index test. Risk of bias regarding reference standard was high in 5 (9.3%) studies. Only 3 (5.6%) studies showed high risk of bias according to the flow and timing. With regards to applicability of the studies, 85.2%, 87.0%, 92.6% of the studies had low concerns in patient selection, index test, and reference standard, respectively. Deeks' funnel plot showed potential publication bias between studies (Supplementary Fig. 3).

## Quantitative analysis

The pooled performance characteristics of all techniques are presented in Supplementary Table 1. The pooled identification rates of SLNB using BD, RI, ICG, RI ? BD, RI ? ICG were 95% (95%CI: 92-97%), 95% (95%CI: 93-97%), 99% (95%CI: 97-100%), 97% (95%CI: 96-98%), and 95% (95%CI: 87-99%), respectively. The pooled sensitivities were 82% (95%CI: 77-86%), 87% (95%CI: 81-92%), 90% (95%CI: 82-95%), 89% (95%CI: 84-93%), and 88% (95%CI: 79-94%), respectively. The pooled accuracies were 94% (95%CI: 91-96%), 95% (95%CI: 92-97%), 98% (95%CI: 95-99%), 97% (95%CI: 95-99%), and 98% (95%CI: 95-99%), respectively. The pooled negative predictive values were 90% (95%CI: 85-94%), 91% (95%CI: 84-96%), 97% (95%CI: 94-99%), 96% (95%CI: 93-98%), and 97% (95%CI: 94-99%), respectively. Overall, ICG and dual tracer method (RI ? BD/ICG) provided improved diagnostic performance compared to the radiocolloid or blue dye.

## Subgroup analysis

The results of subgroup analyses are presented in supplementary Table 2. When solely blue dye was used in SLNB, the mean number of SLNs [ 4 subgroup exhibited a significantly higher sensitivity than SLNs B 4 subgroup (0.87

vs. 0.76, P = 0.014). Studies with tumor diameter \ 30 mm showed a higher sensitivity than studies with tumor diameter C 30 mm (0.88 vs. 0.70, P = 0.011).

When solely ICG was used in SLNB, studies with solely cT1 tumors provided increased sensitivity compared to studies with all cT1-3 tumors (0.95 vs. 0.76, P = 0.049).

No significant factors associated with sensitivity were identified for the use of solely radiocolloid, radiocolloid combined with blue dye, and radiocolloid combined with ICG. No significant predictive factors associated with identification rate were identified for any of the techniques (not shown).

## Discussion

Sentinel lymph node biopsy plays an essential role in the evaluation of lymph node metastasis status and the extent of LN dissection in gastric cancer. However, there is no consensus on the best protocol for its clinical use in SLN mapping and how to supplement or replace other traditional SLNB techniques [6-8]. The current study is a detailed systematic review and meta-analysis performed on peer-reviewed scientific articles to evaluate the different SLNB techniques and their clinical applicability.

L laparoscopic surgery; O opening surgery; ID identification rate; SEN sensibility; SM submucosal; SS subserosal; HE hematoxylin-eosin; IHC immunohistochemistry; NR not report; SLN sentinel lymph node

## Evaluation of lymph node status by SLNB

The results of this meta-analysis indicated that compared with the use of BD or RI method, SLNB using ICG or RI ? BD exhibited higher identification rates (99% and 98%, respectively). Furthermore, the pooled identification rate, sensitivity and NPV for all SLNB techniques steadily increased over time. For SLNB using ICG, the pooled identification rate, sensitivity and NPV of SLNB in patients with gastric cancer have increased from 98%, 88%, and 96% in 2001-2010 to 99%, 92%, and 98% in 2011-2020.

Thus, we believe that the experience of surgeons and application frequency would improve with time, which may be an important factor in the steady increase in diagnostic efficacy of SLNB.

Theoretically, the diagnostic performance of SLNB using RI ? ICG should be significantly improved compared to using solely ICG. Nevertheless, the current study showed no significant difference between patients using solely ICG and RI ? ICG in SLNB with regards to identification rate (99% vs. 95%, P = 0.205) and sensitivity (90% vs. 88%, P = 0.693). Also, there was no significant

| Yaguchi [66]    |   2008 |            20 | T1- T2    | 28               | NR          |        6   | SS               | O      | Naked eyes       |    100   |     100   |          100   |
| Lee, Y. J. [67] |   2008 |            42 | T1- T2    | 33               | HE          |        2.1 | SM               | L      | Naked eyes       |     54.8 |      66.7 |           91.3 |
| Lee, Y. J. [67] |   2008 |            50 | T1- T2    | 31               | HE          |        3.5 | SM               | L      | Naked eyes       |     96   |      85.7 |           95.8 |
| Lee, J. H. [68] |   2008 |            21 | T1        | 31               | HE ? IHC    |        7   | SM               | L      | Naked eyes       |     95.2 |     100   |          100   |

L laparoscopic surgery; O opening surgery; ID identification rate; SEN sensibility; SM submucosal; SS subserosal; HE hematoxylin-eosin; IHC immunohistochemistry; NR not report; SLN sentinel lymph node

difference between patients using solely ICG and RI ? BD in SLNB with regards to sensitivity (90% vs. 89%, P = 0.804). Additionally, SLNB using solely ICG exhibited a higher pooled identification rate than RI ? BD (99% vs. 97%, P = 0.029). These results of the current study

suggested that compared with solely ICG, the dual tracer method (RI ? BD/ICG) did not further increase the identification rate and sensitivity of SLNB.

Furthermore, there are some disadvantages of the use of radioactive substances in dual tracer method. First, the use

of radioactive substances is associated with high costs and potential biohazard, and demands specific logistical arrangements according to regulations regarding handling radioactive substances, therefore restricting its clinical application in some hospitals. Another major limitation of radiocolloid is the shine-through effect from the injection site that can interfere with the ''hot node'' detection [8, 55]. In addition, global shortage of technetium-99 m had been encountered on multiple occasions, and the extremely poor sustainability highlights the need to find alternatives.

Although the blue dye is convenient and cost-effective, the reduced visibility of the blue dye in dense adipose tissue and poor tissue contrast make it extremely difficult to detect SLNs in deep, dark anatomical regions, such as the abdomen [69]. A further potential limitation is the possibility of inducing allergic reactions. These limitations are more critical in laparoscopic surgery. Thus, improvement of the detection method is vital for clinical application of the laparoscopic SLNB.

To overcome these limitations, ICG, as an alternative to the conventional SLN detection methods of BD and RI, has been introduced for SLN mapping during gastric cancer surgery, and has produced favorable outcomes [70].

ICG is a popular diagnostic reagent that is approved for clinical use in the laboratory. ICG possesses a maximum absorption wavelength of 800 nm in the near-infrared range, and emits a maximum fluorescence wavelength of 840 nm when it binds to plasma proteins [41, 69]. Utilizing this principle of ICG, the infrared ray endoscopy system uses infrared rays at a wavelength of around 805 nm, and the fluorescent imaging system is fitted with a light emitting diode (LED) emitting light at the wavelength of 760 nm and a charge-coupled device camera with a cut filter used to filter out light with a wavelength below 820 nm, so as to enhance the visualization of dye within human tissue [15, 16]. Other studies reported that ICG fluorescence imaging allowed more clear and bright visualization than infrared imaging [71]. However, the current study exhibited no significant difference between patients using ICG infrared imaging and fluorescence imaging in SLNB with regards to identification rate (99% vs. 97%, P = 0.342) and sensitivity (96% vs. 82%, P = 0.059).

Many advantages and its clinical applicability of ICG have been emphasized compared with other conventional SLN detection methods. However, the best procedure and suitable criteria of ICG infrared or fluorescence imaging for SLNB, such as ICG concentration, ICG volume, injection site, the observation timing after injection and patient selection, have not been determined [41]. Furthermore, the multi-center prospective study JCOG0302 using ICG was terminated early due to an unacceptable false negative rate, and further analysis conducted by Miyashiro et al. [72] revealed the unreliability of intraoperative

single-plane frozen section and highlighted the impact of the learning curve. Therefore, this method should be performed in the hands of an experienced surgeon.

In the present study, the average number of SLNs per patient obtained by SLNB using ICG or ICG ? RI was considerably higher (ICG: 5.85 SLNs, ICG ? RI: 5.01 SLNs) compared with the use of BD (4.32 SLNs), RI (3.32 SLNs), BD ? RI (4.85 SLNs). This difference might be explained by the low molecular weight of ICG and hence rapid migration through the SLN to second tier nodes, resulting in resection and pathological assessment of multiple nodes.

## Factors influencing the diagnostic performance of SLNB

Of all variables evaluated, selection of patients with solely T1 gastric cancer (vs. T1-T3 gastric cancer; 0.95 vs. 0.76, P = 0.049) was associated with an improved sensitivity for SLNB using ICG. For the use of BD in SLNB, selection of patients with tumor diameter less than 30 mm was associated with an improved SLN sensitivity (vs. C 30 mm; 0.88 vs. 0.69, P = 0.005). No significant factors associated with sensitivity were identified for the use of solely radiocolloid, radiocolloid combined with blue dye, and radiocolloid combined with ICG.

This meta-analysis contains several limitations. First, despite our attempts to include all relevant studies, Deeks' funnel plot asymmetry test still showed potential publication bias, which may limit the stability of the pooled result. Second, the end points were restricted to be SLN identification rate and sensitivity of different SLNB techniques rather than more important outcome measures such as overall survival and locoregional recurrence rate.

## Conclusion

The current meta-analysis provides reliable evidence that favors the use of ICG and dual tracer method (RI ? BD/ ICG) for the identification of the SLN. Considering the high costs and potential biohazard of using radioactive substances in dual tracer method, performing SLNB with ICG is the technique of choice for experienced surgeons.

Funding This research was supported by the Natural Science Foundation of Fujian Province (Grant No. 2018J01377).

## Compliance with ethical standards

Conflict of interest The authors declare that they have no conflict of interest.
